title: 109_s3616
content: The "Affordable Housing Preservation Act of 2006" allows for the exclusion of gain from sales of affordable housing attributed to depreciation under section 1203 of the Internal Revenue Code. The "Affordable Housing Preservation Act of 2006" excludes gain from qualified sales or exchanges of eligible multifamily housing property, limited to depreciation adjustments. Qualified sales or exchanges involve preservation entities agreeing to maintain affordability and use restrictions for a specified period. The "Affordable Housing Preservation Act of 2006" requires preservation entities to maintain affordability and use restrictions on eligible multifamily housing properties, which must be recorded as restrictive covenants. These restrictions apply to all successors of the preservation entity and are consistent with the requirements outlined in the Act. The "Affordable Housing Preservation Act of 2006" mandates that eligible multifamily housing properties must be maintained as affordable housing, meeting specific criteria to qualify. Residents can continue to reside in the property without affecting its affordable housing status. The "Qualified Sale or Exchange" under the Affordable Housing Preservation Act of 2006 requires certification by the housing agency that the transferee is a qualified preservation entity, affordability restrictions will be maintained, new capital will be invested in property restoration, and the transferor's gain exclusion from gross income is determined. The term 'extended use period' refers to the period after the sale of eligible multifamily housing property, lasting up to 30 years or until the property is acquired through foreclosure. The acquisition must not be part of an arrangement to terminate the extended use period. Eligible multifamily housing property is defined as section 1250 property assisted under specific sections. The term 'Preservation Entity' refers to properties assisted under specific housing acts or loans insured under the Housing Act of 1949, excluding properties eligible for tax credits under section 42. A preservation entity, approved by a housing agency, must have the capacity and commitment to acquire and preserve eligible multifamily housing property. The housing agency is responsible for ensuring the preservation entity's plan restores the property's condition, monitoring affordability and use restrictions for at least 30 years. The preservation entity must notify the IRS of any noncompliance with the multifamily housing property requirements. If the property is found to be out of compliance, the entity's tax will be increased by 12.5% of the noncompliant portion. The tax consequences for a qualified sale or exchange of eligible multifamily housing property include a reduction in the determined amount by 3.33 percent for each year the property was in compliance. A portion of the gain from the sale that is treated as ordinary income under section 1250 can be excluded from gross income. The term "housing agency" refers to the State or Federal agency administering the property. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include sections 1202 and 1203 in various paragraphs related to deductions and adjustments for gain from qualified property sales. Amendments include inserting "sections 1202 and 1203" in relevant sections and updating the table of sections accordingly. The amendments made by section 1203 exclude gain from qualified sales of multifamily housing. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2005.
